content:
The Act may be cited as the "Bilingual Education and Technological Advancement Act of 2000" and includes grants for computer software for bilingual education. The "Bilingual Education and Technological Advancement Act of 2000" authorizes grants for computer software for bilingual education. The Secretary of Education may award grants to local educational agencies serving schools with students from low-income families or with low English proficiency. Grants are provided on a competitive basis to assist elementary and secondary schools in obtaining computer software for bilingual education. The grant program under the "Bilingual Education and Technological Advancement Act of 2000" is available for elementary or secondary schools meeting specific criteria. The Secretary conducts an annual study on the program's effectiveness and submits a report to Congress with findings and recommendations. To apply for a grant, a local educational agency must meet the requirements outlined in the Act. To apply for a grant under the "Bilingual Education and Technological Advancement Act of 2000," a local educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary with required information. $80,000,000 is authorized for grants from 2001 to 2005. Grants for computers are available under the "Bilingual Education and Technological Advancement Act of 2000." The Secretary of Education may award grants to local educational agencies for elementary and secondary schools to obtain computers. Grants are mandatory for schools serving a majority of students from low-income families. Eligible schools can use the grant for financial assistance. The Secretary of Education provides grants to local educational agencies for elementary and secondary schools lacking computers. Schools with a majority of students from low-income families are eligible for financial assistance. To apply for a grant, the agency must submit an application to the Secretary. The Secretary is allocated $100,000,000 annually for grants under this section from 2001 to 2005. SEC. 4. INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY TRAINING AND BILINGUAL EDUCATION PROGRAM GRANTS. Grants may be provided to eligible partnerships for information technology training programs for various groups and bilingual education programs. Eligible partnerships must include an institution of higher education and a private organization. To apply for a grant, the partnership must meet certain criteria. To apply for a grant under this program, eligible partnerships must submit an application to the Secretaries with the required information. The Federal share of the cost is 50%, while the non-Federal share can be provided in cash, in kind, or through services. $100,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2001, with additional funding for subsequent years. SEC. 5. Bonus grants for IT certification. The Secretary of Education may grant funds to local educational agencies to award bonuses to teachers who achieve information technology certification, with a limit of $5,000 per teacher. Agencies must submit an application with specific teacher information to be eligible for the grant. The local educational agency can receive funds to award bonuses to teachers who obtain information technology certification, with a cap of $5,000 per teacher. The agency must provide details on the number of certified teachers who have not previously received a bonus. $120,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2001 through 2005 for this purpose. SEC. 6. SCHOLARSHIPS FOR TEACHER TRAINING.

Grants may be awarded to institutions of higher education to provide scholarships to students preparing to enter the teaching workforce. Eligible students must meet criteria for technological and bilingual education. $100,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2001 for this purpose.

SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, a "certified commercial information technology training provider" is defined as a private sector provider certified by software publishers or hardware manufacturers for training in information technology. A "dislocated worker" is defined as per the Workforce Investment Act of 1998. An "elementary school" is also defined. The term "elementary school" is defined as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. "Information technology certification" refers to certification in information technology issued by relevant organizations or state boards. The term "information technology training program" refers to a program for training computer programmers, systems analysts, computer scientists, engineers, and other occupations as determined appropriate by the Secretaries after consultation with relevant entities and associations. The terms defined in this section include "institution of higher education," "local educational agency," "Native American," and "secondary school." These definitions are in accordance with specific acts and laws. The curr_chunk defines terms such as "Secretaries" as the Secretary of Education and the Secretary of Labor, and "veteran" as per the Workforce Investment Act of 1998.
